results.lead_paragraph: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE, 34-12 36th Street, at 35th Avenue, Astoria, Queens. ''Behind the Mirror: American Film in the 1950's,'' through Sept. 3. Tomorrow: Teleplays into film; at 2, Delbert Mann's ''Marty'' (1955); at 4, Sidney Lumet's ''12 Angry Men'' (1957). Sunday at 2: directed by Alfred Hitchcock; at 2, ''Rear Window'' (1954); at 4:30, ''The Wrong Man'' (1957). Tomorrow and Sunday night at 6:30, Jacques Demy's ''Umbrellas of Cherbourg'' (1964). All activities are free with museum admission unless otherwise indicated. Admission: $8.50; the elderly and students, $5.50; ages 5 to 18, $4.50; 4 and under, free. Information: (718) 784-0077.

results.abstract: Article on Doo-Wop Preservation League and Mid-Atlantic Center for Arts summertime four-times weekly Doo-Wop tours of 1950's and 1960's commercial architecture in Wildwood, NJ; photos (M)

headline.main: From the Doo-Wop School of Design

results.snippet: MARYANN SCHROPSDORFF was dressed for a little nostalgia. She had a neat blue-and-white Hawaiian-print shirt, trim jeans and soft-soled saddle shoes. Her boombox played songs like Johnny Ray's ''Cry'' and various Elvis Presley hits. For some, this may...
results.lead_paragraph: MARYANN SCHROPSDORFF was dressed for a little nostalgia. She had a neat blue-and-white Hawaiian-print shirt, trim jeans and soft-soled saddle shoes. Her boombox played songs like Johnny Ray's ''Cry'' and various Elvis Presley hits. For some, this may be the dog-eat-dog, make-a-hard-buck, dot-com era. But for Ms. Schropsdorff and her colleagues at the Doo-Wop Preservation League, it is always the optimistic, futuristic 1950's. Ms. Schropsdorff is a guide for the four-times-weekly Doo-Wop Tours of Wildwood's commercial architecture of the 1950's and 60's. As a trolley (actually a bus made to look like an old-time city trolley) plys the streets of the bustling resort town, Ms. Schropsdorff points out highlights, like Laura's Fudge at Wildwood and Ocean Avenues, where eye-popping neon figures, like the guy stirring a cauldron of fudge, trim the pink-and-blue roof.

''Behind the Mirror: American Film in the 1950's,'' through Sept. 3. Tomorrow at 2 p.m., John Sturges's ''Bad Day at Black Rock'' (1954); at 4:30 p.m., Emile De Antonio's ''Point of Order'' (1964). Sunday at 2 p.m., Richard Brooks's ''Blackboard Jungle'' (1955); at 4 p.m., Gene Fowler Jr.'s ''I Was a Teenage Werewolf'' (1957). Tomorrow and Sunday at 6:30 p.m., Claude Chabrol's ''Bonnes Femmes'' (1960). All activities are free with museum admission unless otherwise indicated. Admission: $8.50; the elderly and students, $5.50; ages 5 to 18, $4.50; 4 and under, free. Information: (718) 784-0077.

results.abstract: Robert R Gilruth, early leader of American space program and director of Johnson Space Center during Apollo lunar landings, dies at age 86; photo (M)

headline.main: Robert Gilruth, 86, Dies; Was Crucial Player at NASA

results.snippet: Robert R. Gilruth, an early leader of the American space program and director of the Johnson Space Center during the Apollo lunar landings, died yesterday in Charlottesville, Va. He was 86 and lived near Warrenton, Va.    Beyond the limelight...
results.lead_paragraph: Robert R. Gilruth, an early leader of the American space program and director of the Johnson Space Center during the Apollo lunar landings, died yesterday in Charlottesville, Va. He was 86 and lived near Warrenton, Va. Beyond the limelight occupied by astronauts, flight directors and former German rocket scientists, the reticent and laconic Mr. Gilruth stood aside when the cheering started, puffing on his pipe. When President John F. Kennedy pinned a medal on him in 1962, he froze, speechless, in front of the microphone. He was used to letting others speak for him and the program.

Tomorrow, two films directed by Otto Preminger: at 1:30 p.m., ''The Man With the Golden Arm'' (1955); at 4 p.m., ''Anatomy of a Murder'' (1959). Sunday at 2 p.m., Elia Kazan's ''Face in the Crowd'' (1957); at 4:30 p.m., Frank Tashlin's ''Will Success Spoil Rock Hunter?'' (1957). Tomorrow and Sunday at 6:30 p.m., Akira Kurosawa's ''Rashomon'' (1951). All activities are free with museum admission unless otherwise indicated. Admission: $8.50; the elderly and students, $5.50; ages 5 to 18, $4.50; 4 and under, free. Information: (718) 784-0077.

results.abstract: Arthur F Anders, an officer of the US Navy gunboat Panay, who took command despite serious wounds after Japanese warplanes attacked it on the Yangtze River in China in 1937, dies at age 96; photo (M)

headline.main: Arthur F. Anders, 96, Hero Aboard U.S. Gunboat in 1937

results.snippet: Arthur F. Anders, an officer of the United States Navy gunboat Panay who took command despite serious wounds after Japanese warplanes attacked it on the Yangtze River in China in 1937, died on Sunday at his home in Rancho Bernardo, Calif. He was 96. ...
results.lead_paragraph: Arthur F. Anders, an officer of the United States Navy gunboat Panay who took command despite serious wounds after Japanese warplanes attacked it on the Yangtze River in China in 1937, died on Sunday at his home in Rancho Bernardo, Calif. He was 96. Lieutenant Anders, nicknamed Tex, was the Panay's executive officer when the attack, which became known as the Panay incident, came on a clear Sunday, Dec. 12, 1937. It was an ominous event in the turbulent years preceding World War II. Japan had invaded China in July of that year, and its troops had seized Nanjing, on the Yangtze in east central China, in November.
